Class HMMWithAlignmentTypePOSTag

  • java.lang.Object
    • HMMWithAlignmentTypePOSTag
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    HMMWithAlignmentTypeNullCorrect

    public class HMMWithAlignmentTypePOSTag
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Implements an HMM model with alignment type for POS-tagged data. The POS tag model for the generative model in the following paper: Joint prediction of word alignment with alignment types.
    Author:
    anahita
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      double aProbability(int iPrime, int i, int I)
      Smoothes p(i|i',I) probabilities by backing-off to a uniform probability 1/I This is an alternative to Och and Ney, 2003 interpolation: \alpha*p(i|i',I) + (1-\alpha)*1/I.

      • forwardWithTScaled

        public GenericPair<double[][],double[]> forwardWithTScaled(double[][][] a,
                                                  double[] pi,
                                                  java.lang.String[] y,
                                                  int N,
                                                  int T,
                                                  java.lang.String[] d,
                                                  java.util.HashMap<Pair,java.lang.Double> t_table)
        Computes forward algorithm for HMM. Note that we re-scale the probabilities to avoid 0 probabilities for long sentences. References: (1) wikipedia Baum Welch algorithm (2) Mathematics of HMM and
        Parameters:
        a - HMM transition parameters
        pi - HMM start parameters
        y - source sentence
        N - length of the target sentence
        T - length of the source sentence
        d - target sentence
        t_table - translation table
        Returns:
        a pair of alphaHat probabilities and c_hat (for alphaHat c_hat refer to reference (2))

      • backwardWithTScaled

        public double[][] backwardWithTScaled(double[][][] a,
                             double[] pi,
                             java.lang.String[] y,
                             int N,
                             int T,
                             java.lang.String[] d,
                             java.util.HashMap<Pair,java.lang.Double> t_table,
                             double[] c_scaled)
        Computes backward algorithm for HMM References: (1) wikipedia Baum Welch algorithm (2) Mathematics of HMM and
        Parameters:
        a - HMM transition parameters
        pi - HMM start parameters
        y - source sentence
        N - length of the target sentence
        T - length of the source sentence
        d - target sentence
        t_table - translation table
        c_scaled - c scaler (computed using forwardWithTScaled method)
        Returns:
        betaHat probabilties

      • initializeModel

        public void initializeModel(int N)
        Initialize HMM parameters (a and pi). t_table is initialized from the t_table of IBM1. Also, tagMap which is a map of alignment types to unique numbers is initialized.
        Parameters:
        N - length of the target sentence

        Returns:

      • tProbability

        public double tProbability(java.lang.String f,
                  java.lang.String e)
        Smoothes t(f|e) parameter by backing-off to a uniform probability 1/V
        Parameters:
        f - source word
        e - target word
        Returns:
        the somoothed t(f|e)

      • aProbability

        public double aProbability(int iPrime,
                  int i,
                  int I)
        Smoothes p(i|i',I) probabilities by backing-off to a uniform probability 1/I This is an alternative to Och and Ney, 2003 interpolation: \alpha*p(i|i',I) + (1-\alpha)*1/I.
        Parameters:
        iPrime - previous target position
        i - current target position
        I - length of target sentence
        Returns:
        either p(i|i',I) or back-off to 1/I

      • sProbability

        public double sProbability(java.lang.String t_f,
                  java.lang.String t_e,
                  java.lang.Integer h)
        This method is used in EM for smoothing p(h|t_f,t_e) parameters. We used to call these s parameters.
        Parameters:
        t_f - POS tag of the source word f
        t_e - POS tag of the target word e
        h - alignment type
        Returns:
        smoothed p(i|i',I)

      • multiplyOneMinusP0H

        public void multiplyOneMinusP0H()
        Following Och and Ney (2000a) approach, for handling source words that have no alignment in the target sentence, we add N empty words (NULLs) to the target sentence and enforce a set of constraints which are implemented in this method.
